instruction: How does the use of a mobile hyperspectral camera compare to traditional methods in estimating soil organic carbon and nitrogen content?
Output:
The use of a mobile hyperspectral camera offers a more cost-efficient and mobile alternative to traditional laboratory methods for estimating soil organic carbon (SOC) and nitrogen content. Traditional methods require soil samples to be collected and analyzed in a laboratory setting, which can be time-consuming and expensive, especially for large-scale monitoring or in remote areas. 

In contrast, the mobile hyperspectral camera allows for on-site imaging of soil samples under controlled laboratory conditions. This camera operates in the visible-near infrared wavelength range and captures spectral images of the soil samples. These images can then be used to estimate the SOC and nitrogen content using machine learning techniques.

The study mentioned in the text collected 191 soil samples from different land use types in Kenya and used the mobile hyperspectral camera to image the samples. The carbon and nitrogen content of the samples were determined using a combustion analyzer. The results showed that the mobile hyperspectral camera, combined with machine learning algorithms, performed well in estimating SOC and nitrogen content. The cross-validated R-2 value was approximately 0.8, indicating a strong correlation between the spectral images and the actual carbon and nitrogen content. The root mean square error (RMSE) was one percentage point, further demonstrating the accuracy of the estimation.
